taxPlanning.title: Tax Payment Period Extension Instruction No. 142/2011
taxPlanning.excerpt: According to **Proclamation No. 983/2008** on Tax Administration, it has been established that a taxpayer who is unable to pay their tax liability in full or in a lump sum may request an extension of the payment period from the Ministry of Revenue.
taxPlanning.fullContent: According to **Proclamation No. 983/2008** on Tax Administration, it has been established that a taxpayer who is unable to pay their tax liability in full or in a lump sum may request an extension of the payment period from the Ministry of Revenue. Accordingly, in relation to the directive issued by the Ministry of Revenue, it is understood that when a taxpayer is unable to pay their tax liability in full or in a lump sum, the Ministry may grant an extension of the payment period. This directive has been issued to implement this provision. When a taxpayer is unable to pay their tax liability in a lump sum, it is appropriate to create a fair and accountable system by entering into an extended payment agreement and establishing a responsible operational procedure. This directive also details the conditions under which an extension of the tax payment period may be allowed or prohibited. Conditions Under Which Tax Payment Extensions Are Allowed: - The taxpayer is unable to pay their tax liability in a lump sum. - The taxpayer is not in a high-risk category at the time of receiving the tax assessment or tax calculation notice. - The taxpayer has requested to pay their tax liability and has provided a bank guarantee equivalent to the liability, especially when their assets are seized or auctioned due to high-risk categorization. Conditions Under Which Tax Payment Extensions Are Not Allowed: - The tax liability is not a direct tax or is subject to withholding from the taxpayer's account. - The taxpayer has previously been granted a payment extension but failed to pay within the agreed period without a valid reason. - The amount of tax liability for which the extension is requested is subject to the taxpayer's discretion. Additionally, the taxpayer must respond within 30 days of receiving the tax payment extension decision from the tax authority. If the taxpayer fails to respond within this period, the extension request will be denied. Duration of Payment Extensions: The directive specifies the duration of payment extensions based on the taxpayer's category and the amount of tax liability: - For High Taxpayers: - Tax liability between **750,000 ETB and 2.5 million ETB**: Up to **6 months**. - Tax liability between **2.5 million ETB and 3.75 million ETB**: Up to **8 months**. - Tax liability between **3.75 million ETB and 5 million ETB**: Up to **10 months**. - Tax liability above **5 million ETB**: Up to **12 months**. - For Medium Taxpayers: - Tax liability between **50,000 ETB and 125,000 ETB**: Up to **3 months**. - Tax liability between **125,000 ETB and 750,000 ETB**: Up to **8 months**. - Tax liability between **2.5 million ETB and 3.75 million ETB**: Up to **10 months**. - Tax liability above **3.75 million ETB**: Up to **12 months**. - For Small Taxpayers: - Tax liability between **5,000 ETB and 12,500 ETB**: Up to **3 months**. - Tax liability between **12,501 ETB and 75,000 ETB**: Up to **6 months**. - Tax liability between **75,001 ETB and 250,000 ETB**: Up to **8 months**. - Tax liability between **250,001 ETB and 750,000 ETB**: Up to **10 months**. - Tax liability above **750,000 ETB**: Up to **12 months**. - For Micro Taxpayers: - Tax liability between **1,000 ETB and 10,000 ETB**: Up to **3 months**. - Tax liability between **10,000 ETB and 20,000 ETB**: Up to **6 months**. - Tax liability between **20,000 ETB and 40,000 ETB**: Up to **8 months**. - Tax liability between **40,001 ETB and 60,000 ETB**: Up to **10 months**. - Tax liability above **60,001 ETB**: Up to **12 months**. Implementation of Payment Extensions: The extension of the payment period becomes effective after the taxpayer and the tax authority sign a payment agreement. If the taxpayer fails to meet the terms of the agreement, they may not be granted another extension. Additionally, the taxpayer must pay at least **25% of the tax liability** upfront to qualify for an extension. If the taxpayer's assets have been seized, they must provide a bank guarantee equivalent to the tax liability to lift the seizure. The directive also outlines the process for appealing tax decisions and how payments made during the appeal process will be credited toward the tax liability. Special Cases: In special cases, the taxpayer may request a further extension by submitting a request to the branch office. The branch office will review the taxpayer's payment history and the reasons for the request, then forward the case to the Tax Debt Administration Directorate. The Directorate will make a recommendation to the Minister or their representative, who may reduce the upfront payment requirement to **15%** of the tax liability. Enforcement in Addis Ababa and Dire Dawa: The directive also applies to the revenue authorities of Addis Ababa and Dire Dawa, which will follow the same procedures as outlined above. Penalties for Non-Compliance: If a taxpayer fails to comply with the terms of the payment extension agreement, they will not be eligible for another extension. Additionally, penalties for late payment under **Article 105** of the Tax Administration Proclamation will not apply if the taxpayer adheres to the terms of the agreement.

auditPreparation.title: Rental Income Tax
auditPreparation.excerpt:
1. Taxable Rental Income
Taxable rental income refers to the income derived by a taxpayer from renting out a property during the tax year, after deducting the total allowable expenses for the taxpayer.
auditPreparation.fullContent:
1. Taxable Rental Income
Taxable rental income refers to the income derived by a taxpayer from renting out a property during the tax year, after deducting the total allowable expenses for the taxpayer. The gross income from renting out a property includes the following:
- Any amount received by the taxpayer during the tax year as rent or similar payments under the rental agreement, including rent increases,
- Payments made by the tenant on behalf of the landlord during the tax year under the rental agreement,
- Any bond, guarantee, or similar amount held by the taxpayer for damages to the property during the tax year but not utilized,
- Any amount spent by the tenant for the renovation or improvement of the property in addition to the rent paid under the rental agreement,
- The total income received by the taxpayer from renting out the property along with any items, which also includes rental income from the items.

2. Sublessors
Sublessor's taxable income refers to the income received by a sublessor during the tax year from subleasing a property, after deducting the rent paid to the main lessor and other expenses incurred to earn the income.
If a sublessor fails to pay the tax, the property owner who authorized the sublease is responsible for paying the tax.

3. Notification of New Rental Property
A contractor or property owner who constructs a property for rent must notify the local administration or district administration of the name, address, and tax identification number of the person responsible for paying tax on the rental income, once the property is completed or rented out.
The local administration or district administration must provide the information obtained from the contractor or property owner to the tax authority.

4. Rental Income Tax Rates
The rental income tax rate for organizations is 30% (thirty percent).
The rental income tax rates for individuals are as follows:

5. Deductible Expenses
For taxpayers not required to maintain accounting records, the following expenses are deductible when calculating taxable rental income:
- Payments made by the taxpayer to the government or city administration during the tax year for land or property-related taxes, excluding income tax,
- 50% of the total amount spent on housing, furniture, equipment storage, maintenance, and replacement of aging furniture and equipment from the gross rental income.
The above 50% deduction does not apply to taxpayers required to maintain accounting records.

For taxpayers required to maintain accounting records, necessary expenses incurred to earn the income and paid by the taxpayer during the tax year are deductible. These expenses include:
- Land lease payments,
- Maintenance costs, depreciation of the property, furniture, and equipment,
- Interest and carbon taxes,
- Payments made to the government or city administration for land or property-related taxes, excluding income tax.

6. Rental Losses
Provisions in the law and regulations regarding the carryover of business income tax losses also apply to rental losses incurred by taxpayers.

7. Rental Payments Covering More Than One Year
If a lessor or sublessor receives rental income covering more than one year under Article 15(5) of the Proclamation, the total rental income is considered as received in the tax year it was received. However, the tax on this income is calculated by dividing it over the tax years it covers.

8. Rental of Business Assets
Income derived from renting out business assets, including goods, equipment, and properties, as part of the normal business operations, is taxable under Schedule 'C' of the Proclamation.

businessGrowth.title: The instructions issued regarding the licensing, management, use, disposal and control of receipt printing
businessGrowth.excerpt: The issuance, management, use, distribution, and control of receipts are governed by Directive No. 110/2008, which is based on the Federal Income Tax and Tax Administration Proclamations.
businessGrowth.fullContent:
The issuance, management, use, distribution, and control of receipts are governed by Directive No. 110/2008, which is based on the Federal Income Tax and Tax Administration Proclamations. According to these regulations, taxpayers classified under 'Category A' and 'Category B' are required to maintain accounting records, hold necessary information, and use legal receipts. Although taxpayers under 'Category C' are not legally obligated to maintain accounting records, they are encouraged to do so voluntarily. Therefore, taxpayers under 'Category A' and 'Category B' must ensure that their transactions are supported by receipts when conducting their business activities.

Information Required When Applying for a Receipt Printing Permit
According to Sub-Article 1 of Article 5 of Directive No. 110/2008 issued by the Ministry of Revenue, the following information must be submitted when applying for a receipt printing permit:
1. For organizations that have not yet started business operations or are not engaged in commercial activities but are in the investment process and are responsible for reduced income tax, the taxpayer identification number (TIN) and investment certificate must be provided to issue receipts for reduced tax purposes.
2. For taxpayers engaged in business activities, the taxpayer identification number (TIN), legal business registration, business license, and business name must be included on the issued receipts.
3. For agents responsible for reduced value-added tax (VAT), the taxpayer identification number (TIN) must be provided.
4. If a taxpayer requests their organization's logo to be included on the receipts, they must provide proof of registration of the logo from the Ethiopian Intellectual Property Office.

Detailed Information to Be Included on Receipts
According to Sub-Article 2 of Article 7 of the Directive, sales receipts must include at least the following basic information:
1. The full name, address, and registered business name of the supplier.
2. The supplier's taxpayer identification number (TIN), VAT number, and the date of tax registration.
3. The serial number of the receipt.
4. The full name, address, and taxpayer identification number (TIN) of the purchaser.
5. The type and quantity of goods delivered or services provided.
6. The amount of VAT or turnover tax applicable to the taxable transaction.
7. The total sales or transaction amount in words and figures.
8. The date the receipt was issued.
9. The name and signature of the employee who prepared and/or received the payment.
10. The name of the issuing organization, taxpayer identification number (TIN), date of issuance, and the certificate of competence of the issuer.
11. The letter number and date of authorization from the tax authority for the issuance of the receipt.

Responsibilities of Taxpayers Regarding Receipt Usage
According to Article 19 of the Directive, any taxpayer using receipts recognized by the tax authority must adhere to the following responsibilities:
- Do not use unauthorized or illegal receipts.
- Do not record different information on the original and duplicate copies of receipts.
- Ensure the actual sales price or amount is clearly stated on the receipt.
- Do not allow receipts issued to one taxpayer to be used by another.
- Do not conduct sales without issuing receipts.
- Do not refuse to issue receipts to customers who request them.
- Do not issue receipts with the same serial number for the same type of transaction.
- Do not use receipts issued before the tax authority granted the printing permit or after the permit has been revoked.
- Ensure all receipts contain the information specified in Article 7 of the Directive.
- Issue receipts with original and duplicate copies.
- Safely store receipts and retain receipts for transactions until the tax law specifies otherwise.
- Submit receipts when requested for audit or tax assessment.
- Display the receipt usage ledger in a visible location and ensure it contains accurate information.
- Issue manually printed receipts with the tax authority's approval if the sales recording device is unavailable.
- Immediately forward the second copy of the receipt to the accounting department along with supporting documents.
- Use receipts in sequential order and notify the tax office if receipts are used out of sequence.
- Maintain separate receipt sequences for different business locations or sectors.

Conclusion
According to the Proclamations, any taxpayer required to maintain accounting records must register the type and quantity of receipts with the tax authority before issuing them. Any person providing receipt printing services must verify that the receipts have been registered with the tax authority before printing them upon the taxpayer's request.

In general, any taxpayer required to maintain accounting records must issue receipts for their transactions and retain the necessary information.

In our city, notices such as 'Do not pay without a receipt!' are commonly seen in cafes, restaurants, beverage stores, and other businesses. These notices encourage the public to demand receipts. However, how many of us actually request or accept receipts when conducting transactions? How accountable are we in reporting transactions conducted without receipts to the relevant government authorities? Requesting and accepting receipts is not only our right but also a guarantee for our purchases. Conducting transactions without receipts creates unnecessary pressure on the legal business system and government revenue. Working together to prevent this is the only solution.
